original_data.question: A 35-year-old man visits your office for his annual health checkup. He was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder 6 months ago, which is being treated with citalopram. He comments that his symptoms have improved since initiating the prescribed therapy; however, in the past 2 months, he has been unable to have sexual intercourse due to weak tumescence and low libido. His blood pressure is 122/74 mm Hg, heart rate is 75/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Physical examination reveals regular heart and lung sounds. What is the appropriate step in the management of this patient?

model_response:
The patient is experiencing a common sexual side effect associated with the use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is to switch him to a different antidepressant, such as bupropion. Bupropion is an effective antidepressant that is not associated with sexual side effects. The other options listed are not appropriate choices because they are also SSRIs and therefore may cause similar sexual side effects.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
Occurring or done each year.
An appraisal or evaluation of a patient's condition by a clinician that is based on a physical exam, medical history, and the patient's account of symptoms.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.

An anxiety disorder characterized by excessive and difficult-to-control worry about a number of life situations. The worry is accompanied by restlessness, fatigue, inability to concentrate, irritability, muscle tension, and/or sleep disturbance and lasts for at least 6 months.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.

A furancarbonitrile that is one of the SELECTIVE SEROTONIN REUPTAKE INHIBITORS used as an antidepressant. The drug is also effective in reducing ethanol uptake in alcoholics and is used in depressed patients who also suffer from TARDIVE DYSKINESIA in preference to tricyclic antidepressants, which aggravate dyskinesia.

Work consisting of a critical or explanatory note written to discuss, support, or dispute an article or other presentation previously published. It may take the form of an article, letter, editorial, etc. It appears in publications under a variety of names: comment, commentary, editorial comment, viewpoint, etc.
Condition changed and/or recovered

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
The sexual union of a male and a female, a term used for human only.
Having strength, power, or intensity less than average or expected.
Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation
A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.

The psychic drive or energy associated with sexual instinct in the broad sense (pleasure and love-object seeking). It may also connote the psychic energy associated with instincts in general that motivate behavior.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.
Noises, normal and abnormal, heard on auscultation over any part of the RESPIRATORY TRACT.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
